message_1: Consider the set of all continuous functions $f:[0,1]\to\mathbb{R}$. Determine if the following sequence of functions converges pointwise: $$f_{n}(x) = \frac{x^{n}}{1+x^{n}}.$$
message_2:
To determine if the sequence of functions $f_n(x) = \frac{x^n}{1+x^n}$ converges pointwise, we need to find the limit of the function as $n$ goes to infinity for each $x$ in the interval $[0, 1]$.

Let's consider three cases:

1. $x = 0$: In this case, $f_n(0) = \frac{0^n}{1+0^n} = \frac{0}{1} = 0$ for all $n$. So, $\lim_{n\to\infty} f_n(0) = 0$.

2. $x = 1$: In this case, $f_n(1) = \frac{1^n}{1+1^n} = \frac{1}{1+1} = \frac{1}{2}$ for all $n$. So, $\lim_{n\to\infty} f_n(1) = \frac{1}{2}$.

3. $0 < x < 1$: In this case, since $0 < x < 1$, we have $0 < x^n < 1$ for all $n$. As $n$ goes to infinity, $x^n$ goes to 0 (because $0 < x < 1$). So, we have $\lim_{n\to\infty} x^n = 0$. Therefore, $$\lim_{n\to\infty} f_n(x) = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{x^n}{1+x^n} = \frac{\lim_{n\to\infty} x^n}{1+\lim_{n\to\infty} x^n} = \frac{0}{1+0} = 0.$$

So, for all $x$ in the interval $[0, 1]$, the sequence of functions $f_n(x) = \frac{x^n}{1+x^n}$ converges pointwise to the function $f(x) = \begin{cases} 0, & \text{if } 0 \le x < 1 \\ \frac{1}{2}, & \text{if } x = 1 \end{cases}$.
